awd_titl_txt: An Integrated Approach to Understanding Evolutionary Transformations in Craniodental and Locomotor Specializations
awd_abstract_narration:
Carnivores (bears, wolves, lions, seals and relatives) are key predators in modern ecosystems. Understanding their evolutionary relationships is fundamental to interpreting other knowledge (biological, medical, ecological) derived from carnivore research. By developing the most comprehensive framework for interrelationships of living and fossil carnivores (>100 species) using 400 anatomical and over 30,000 genetic characteristics, and integrating novel 3-D imaging, mathematical, and engineering-derived computer modeling tools, this research will reconstruct carnivore evolutionary relationships and decipher their adaptations for critical ecosystem roles over time.

Analyzing how feeding function of skulls changed over time, and how species developed locomotion and cognitive specializations during major habitat transitions (land-to-water, tree-to-ground), this research will rigorously test previous hypotheses that these changes represent responses to significant environmental changes over the past 65 million years. This project will use cutting-edge research on these charismatic mammals to enrich museum exhibitions and create online multimedia (serving 5 million visitors [500,000 schoolchildren] and 12 million online learners annually).  This project will also implement high school and college education and research training programs, including workshops, development of new graduate courses, training for three postdoctoral scientists, and instructional programs for dozens of high school students and undergraduate students.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY

por.por_cntn:
The mammalian order Carnivora is one of the most successful groups of predatory mammals living today, with more than 280 living species and hundreds of fossil species, including well known members such as dogs, cats, otters, bears, hyaenas, seals, and weasels. The last common ancestor of this group lived over 40 million years ago, and paleontologists have identified a host of fossil species that fall between this last common ancestor and all other mammals. These ancient fossil species, together with the living species and their extinct close relatives, form the group formally known as Carnivoramorpha. Carnivoramorphans display a broad array of morphologies and ecological behaviors, whose deep time evolutionary trends and origins have awaited detailed investigation using modern quantitative methods and analyzed within a robust framework of evolutionary relationships (systematics and phylogeny).

 

Our project conducted analyses to develop the most comprehensive reconstruction of evolutionary relationships for this group to date, incorporating extensive DNA data, as well as anatomical information for a wide variety of living and extinct forms (Goal 1). This ‘family tree’ then was used as a necessary framework for addressing the other aims of the project, focusing on distinguishing the historical (ancestry), functional (such as diet or locomotion style), or environmental influences on the complex relationships between skull shape and biomechanics (Goal 2), and understanding the anatomy and physiology of the inner ear – the center of not just hearing, but also of balance and orientation (Goal 3). Our research resulted in the creation of high-resolution 3-D models of craniodental (skull-tooth) and intracranial (internal bony structures and endocast impressions of the brain, inside the skull) anatomy based on high-resolution X-ray computer tomography scans: using sophisticated computer programs, we built and analyzed 3-D simulation models of skulls and jaws for more than 50 modern and fossil species, and 3-D models of inner ears for over 100 modern and fossil species. We used new 3-D quantitative methods and analyses on those models for reconstructing the biomechanical forces and constraints exerted over the skull or the jaw in species exhibiting distinct dietary preferences, for understanding the relationship between skull shapes, biomechanics, and ecological and non-ecological factors (Goal 2) and for analyzing shape patterns of the inner ear in relation to species locomotor specializations (ranging across digging, land-dwelling runners or walkers, tree-dwelling arboreal specialists, or aquatic forms; notably analyzing for adaptations to high-speed hunting and to aquatic and arboreal environments; Goal 3). Specific hypotheses on diet and locomotion tested in modern species served as a model to infer the paleoecology of fossil species. Ultimately, this research project produced new datasets and an extensive series of scientific publications that were used to clarify the evolution of key anatomical-functional structures in the skull across our new tree of species interrelationships for Carnivoramorpha, in addition to providing new biological research tools derived from engineering methods, and shape analyses of 3-D biological objects. These tools and approaches are broadly applicable for analyzing morphological traits in other vertebrate groups.

 

The broader impacts of our research included: 1) Production of two Science Bulletins videos, an American Museum of Natural History (AMNH) online and in-school educational program featuring the latest research in Biology and Geosciences; AMNH News and Blogs posts on an Inner Mongolian expedition collecting carnivores and other fossil mammals; and incorporation of artists in illustrating and better communicating outcomes of the scientific research for the general public; all available to the 12 million yearly unique online visitors to the Museum’s website; 2) Contributions to an online graduate course for teachers, as well as numerous educational and public outreach programs (e.g., Discovery Room, Facebook Live videos, BridgeUp program in computer science for high school girls, media interviews and press coverage of research, etc.); 2) Mentoring of 9 NSF Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) students and 3 other students, from high-school to undergraduate level (including 6 women), with each involved in poster or talk presentations in regional and international meetings, and many leading or participating in co-authorship of peer-reviewed scientific publications, as well as receiving training in various aspects of scientific research (X-ray CT scanning technology and computerized 3-D reconstructions, anatomy, systematics, evolutionary and environmental biology, computer modeling and engineering simulations, mathematical principles of biomechanics, and shape and statistical analyses); 3) The 3 Co-PIs proposing and leading a Poster Symposium on 3-D Imaging Methods and Analyses in Paleontology at the annual meeting of the world’s largest paleontological professional society; workshops for REU interns, other students, and postdoctoral fellows at the AMNH on CT Methods and Applications in Biological and Geological Sciences; and 2 co-PIs teaching as lecturers in an AMNH Richard Gilder Graduate School (RGGS) graduate course on Microscopy and Imaging Methods for Comparative Biology; and 4) Enhancing training and providing career-development mentoring for 3 post-doctoral scholars (2 women, 1 Asian-American man).
